What are the necessary files required to update the ARM CLI wallet for Verus?

To update the ARM CLI wallet for Verus, you need to download the latest Wallet from the Verus website (https://verus.io/wallet). Additionally, you will need to have the Verus `Wallet.dat`, Chaindata, and `VRSC.conf` files in their standard locations.

# Updating the ARM CLI wallet.Attention: Read it completely before use.## Necessary files:Link 1: [Download latest Wallet](https://verus.io/wallet)## Verus `Wallet.dat`, Chaindata & `VRSC.conf` standard locations
 * ARM Linux:		`~/.komodo/VRSC`Note: Due to the size of the blockchain, on an ARM installation this directory is usually stored on a mounted external hard drive.
This will have its own file path that was specified when the drive was mounted.
Thus the path to `~/.komodo/VRSC` directory is likely to be user-specified & thus non-standard on an ARM.---(NB This version is aimed at inexperienced users, so it includes the associated routine/basic Linux commands.
You will need access to the relevant directories, which may require sudo priveleges)(NB Raspberry Pi ARM boards lack some instruction sets to mine, though the Pi3 & Pi4 are ARM64 & can be used as staking devices if an ARM64 operating system is installed)---## Procedure:
Where are the standard locations for Verus `Wallet.dat`, Chaindata, and `VRSC.conf` files on ARM Linux?

On ARM Linux, the standard location for Verus `Wallet.dat`, Chaindata, and `VRSC.conf` files is `~/.komodo/VRSC`. However, due to the large size of the blockchain, this directory is often stored on a mounted external hard drive, which may have a non-standard file path specified by the user.

This will have its own file path that was specified when the drive was mounted.
Thus the path to `~/.komodo/VRSC` directory is likely to be user-specified & thus non-standard on an ARM.---(NB This version is aimed at inexperienced users, so it includes the associated routine/basic Linux commands.

Can I use a Raspberry Pi ARM board to mine Verus coins?
No, Raspberry Pi ARM boards lack some instruction sets required for mining. However, if you have a Raspberry Pi3 or Pi4, you can use them as staking devices if you install an ARM64 operating system.
